content: >http://www.nydailynews.com/opinions/2009/05/01/2009-05-01_well_shut_his_mouth.html Staying out of enclosed public spaces, particularly commercial aircraft, and particularly those aircraft coming out of Mexico, might be a fairly prudent thing to do since there is a definite indication the latest 'NAFTA' virus is airborne. But the 'conventional wisdom' that governs such things, as in the AIDS virus, seems to be that the sooner we all get it, the easier it will be to deal with. Biden's right. Travelling sick or with the sick, like it has always been, is the best, read only, way to spread an infectious disease. To-day's aircraft just make that transmission faster, and easier. To-day's air transportation is a potential disease vector. This message has been edited. Last edited by: popsiq, Fri 01 May 2009 06:59 AM

But the 'conventional wisdom' that governs such things, as in the AIDS virus, seems to be that the sooner we all get it, the easier it will be to deal with. Biden's right. Travelling sick or with the sick, like it has always been, is the best, read only, way to spread an infectious disease. To-day's aircraft just make that transmission faster, and easier. content: quote: Originally posted by popsiq: >http://www.nydailynews.com/opinions/2009/05/01/2009-05-01_well_shut_his_mouth.html Staying out of enclosed public spaces, particularly commercial aircraft, and particularly those aircraft coming out of Mexico, might be a fairly prudent thing to do since there is a definite indication the latest 'NAFTA' virus is airborne. But the 'conventional wisdom' that governs such things, as in the AIDS virus, seems to be that the sooner we all get it, the easier it will be to deal with. Biden's right. Travelling sick or with the sick, like it has always been, is the best, read only, way to spread an infectious disease. To-day's aircraft just make that transmission faster, and easier. To-day's air transportation is a potential disease vector. Biden said nothing about traveling while sick, his remarks simply addressed traveling. As his words directly contradicted those of the President a visit to the "hotseat" is more than appropriate. The clean up squad added the reference to being sick.

content: quote: Originally posted by adminnco1: quote: Originally posted by popsiq: >http://www.nydailynews.com/opinions/2009/05/01/2009-05-01_well_shut_his_mouth.html Staying out of enclosed public spaces, particularly commercial aircraft, and particularly those aircraft coming out of Mexico, might be a fairly prudent thing to do since there is a definite indication the latest 'NAFTA' virus is airborne. But the 'conventional wisdom' that governs such things, as in the AIDS virus, seems to be that the sooner we all get it, the easier it will be to deal with. Biden's right. Travelling sick or with the sick, like it has always been, is the best, read only, way to spread an infectious disease. To-day's aircraft just make that transmission faster, and easier. To-day's air transportation is a potential disease vector. Biden said nothing about traveling while sick, his remarks simply addressed traveling. As his words directly contradicted those of the President a visit to the "hotseat" is more than appropriate. The clean up squad added the reference to being sick. Biden cautioned against travelling in enclosed places, he specified aircraft and subways as example, in light of the current flu situation. I was the one who 'cooked up' the notion that travelling 'sick' spread disease. Maybe Joe would disagree with me, but until airlines start checking passengers' health - as well as shoes and credit status, flying anywhere, anytime, could be bad for your health - more so in a pandemic situation.
quote: Originally posted by adminnco1: quote: Originally posted by popsiq: >http://www.nydailynews.com/opinions/2009/05/01/2009-05-01_well_shut_his_mouth.html Staying out of enclosed public spaces, particularly commercial aircraft, and particularly those aircraft coming out of Mexico, might be a fairly prudent thing to do since there is a definite indication the latest 'NAFTA' virus is airborne. But the 'conventional wisdom' that governs such things, as in the AIDS virus, seems to be that the sooner we all get it, the easier it will be to deal with. Biden's right. Travelling sick or with the sick, like it has always been, is the best, read only, way to spread an infectious disease. To-day's aircraft just make that transmission faster, and easier. To-day's air transportation is a potential disease vector. Biden said nothing about traveling while sick, his remarks simply addressed traveling. As his words directly contradicted those of the President a visit to the "hotseat" is more than appropriate. The clean up squad added the reference to being sick.
reply: Biden cautioned against travelling in enclosed places, he specified aircraft and subways as example, in light of the current flu situation. I was the one who 'cooked up' the notion that travelling 'sick' spread disease. Maybe Joe would disagree with me, but until airlines start checking passengers' health - as well as shoes and credit status, flying anywhere, anytime, could be bad for your health - more so in a pandemic situation.

content: quote: Originally posted by klassylady25: What people hate/like about Biden, is that he sometimes talks with some common sense. Actually its more along the lines that every time Biden opens his mouth anything can come out whether its factual or not. In this case he may have a point. On previous cases of his ineptitude of shutting his mouth its the latter. Pretty soon the VP will find he has a case of the lock jaw imposed upon him by the current President.
